// Functions that manipulate text in various ways.

// Functions that allow for the control of script trigger execution.
// Functions that assist with building URL strings.
// Functions that ease working with utility windows.

dialog 2.0.0 ============ The `dialog` module includes two types of features. The first is just a single script that ddisplays a dialog in a loop until tests have been passed. Failed tests alter the dialog box informing the user of the requirements to pass the test. But FileMaker doesn't support more complex dialogs, such as a dialog box that includes menus or even a portal. Card windows are perfect for this, however, and the other set of scripts supports using layouts as dialog boxes for record creation and editing. The module includes features for validating the data in a creation or edit dialog and support for using the keyboard to cancel or confirm the dialog. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library - This file's `primary-key` module - This file's `window` module Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the this file. 2. Import the `primary-key` and `window` modules if they aren't already present in your solution. 3. Import the `dialog` script folder. 4. If you want to take advantage of the automated testing, create a layout with a context into `FUNIT` and set it up like the `test_dialog` layout in this file. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- For simple dialogs, call `dialog-loop: Begin Loop ( Title ; BaseMsg ; Inputs ; Tests ; Msgs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )`. See the comments in that script for the needs of the various parameters. For layout based dialogs, you have a few options. - To prepare the dialog window: - For the layout that will serve as a popin dialog, assign the `dialog: onRecordCommit ( IsValid )` script to the `OnRecordCommit` script trigger, passing a value for the `Validation` parameter that is `True` when the data is valid or an error message when validation fails. - Assign the `dialog: onObjectKeystroke Layout` script to the layout's `OnLayoutKeystroke` trigger (or ensure it's executed if you use a dispatch system for script triggers). - For any large text fields that should capture carriage returns, assign the `dialog: onObjectKeystroke Long Text Field` script to the field's `OnObjectKeystroke` trigger (or ensure it's executed if you use a dispatch system for script triggers). - Assign the `dialog: Save` script to execute with a button that should save changes and close the popin window. - Assign the `dialog: Cancel` script to execute with a button that should cancel changes to data in the popin window. - If you use the `window` module, popins windows will be centered horizontally within their parent window and offset from the top of their parent window by 50 pixels with a size resulting from an `Adjust Window [ Resize to Fit ]` script call. > Note: Since the dialog window creates a modal dialog that can only be closed via the `Close Window` script step, introducing the possibility of the window being stuck open during development, the `dialog: Cancel` script has an emergency exit. If a developer (logged in with "[Full Access]" privileges) clicks a button attached to this script while holding down the "Shift" key, the window will immediately close. - To activate the dialog window designed to edit a record, execute the `dialog: Edit ( Rule ; Layout ; ID {; PreCommit ; PostCommit ; PostClose } )`, passing the following parameters: - `Auth`: Send the string `True` if the user has permission to edit the record, or an error message that should be displayed to the user if they do not have permission. - `Layout`: The name of the layout that should be used for the popin window. - `ID`: The primary key of the record to present to the user for editing. - `Callbacks`: A let-notation dictionary of callbacks to perform, with the following potential keys: - `pre_commit`: A script name to execute before committing - `post_commit`: A script name to execute after committing - `post_close`: A script name to execute after closing the dialog - To activate the popin window and create a new record, execute the `popin: New ( Rule ; Layout {; Fields ; Values ; PreCommit ; PostCommit ; PostClose } )` script, passing the following parameters: - `Rule`: Send the string `"OK"` if the user has permission to create the record, or an error message that should be displayed to the user if they do not have permission. - `Layout`: The name of the layout that should be used for the popin window. - `Fields`: The optional list of fields that should be assigned values to the new record. - `Values`: The optional list of values to assign to the fields listed in the `Fields` parameter. Note that these two lists must have equal value counts. - `Callbacks`: A let-notation dictionary of callbacks to perform, with the following potential keys: - `pre_commit`: A script name to execute before committing - `post_commit`: A script name to execute after committing - `post_close`: A script name to execute after closing the dialog Here is an example of using the script parameter custom functions to pass parameters to `popin: New ( Rule ; Layout {; Fields ; Values ; PreCommit ; PostCommit ; PostClose } )`: Let ( [ _auth = Case ( Get ( AccountPrivilegeSetName ) = "Management" ; True ; "You must be a manager to create invoice records." ) ; _layout = "Dialog New Invoice" ; _fields = List ( GetFieldName ( INV::date_created ) ; GetFieldName ( INV::time_created ) ) ; _values = List ( Get ( CurrentDate ) ; Get ( CurrentTime ) ) ; _pre_commit = "check_invoice_line_items" ; _post_commit = "show_invoice_preview" ; _post_close = "update_screen" ] ; script.Param ( "Auth" ; _auth ) & script.Param ( "Layout" ; _layout ) & script.Param ( "Fields" ; _fields ) & script.Param ( "Values" ; _values ) & script.Param ( "PreCommit" ; _pre_save ) & script.Param ( "PostCommit" ; _post_save ) & script.Param ( "PostClose" ; _post_cose ) ) To Do ----- Try to find a way to full automate testing this module. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-07-30 1.0.1 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-05-01 - Minor edits to `popin priv: New...` 1.0.2 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-05-25 - Fix variable typos. 1.1.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-25 - Refactor to conform to current conventions, take advantage of `Perform Script by Name` 2.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-09-21 - Combined popin and dialog modules [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: Return the name of a popin window's title given the layout and primary key value. Parameters: Layout: The name of the layout from which to calculate the window name. ID: Optional: The primary key of the record being edited on edit popins. Return: A let-notation dictionary with a key of `~window_name` that should be the window's title. Version: 17-12-01 - Charles Ross 20-01-12 - Charles Ross - Update to work with current conventions and funit testing
DO NOT EDIT ABOVE THIS LINE

Calculation.Text: Let ( [ _title = Case ( dev.IsSet ( $ID ) ; "Edit " ; "New " ) & Trim ( Substitute ( $Layout ; "popin" ; dev.Nil ) ) & Case ( dev.IsSet ( $ID ) ; " (" & $ID & ")" ; dev.Nil ) ] ; _title )

ScriptReference.name: dialog: Begin Loop ( Title ; BaseMsg ; Inputs ; Tests ; Msgs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )

Comment.value: Purpose: Provide a looping custom message dialog box that returns up to three input fields after conditions have been met or the user has canceled. Parameters: Title: The dialog box title. BaseMsg: The beginning message for the dialog box which is append after any conditions fail. Inputs: The number of input fields, an integer from 0 to 3. Tests: A let-notation array of tests that should be passed. Each test should be `Evaluate`able. Msgs: A let-notation array of matching messages when conditions fail. Msgs and Tests must match in count. Btns: Optional: A let-notation array of button names, defaults to "OK" and "Cancel". If provided, must include at least two buttons. Labels: Optional: A let-notation array of labels. If not provided, no labels are given. PWStart: Optional: The first input field to make a password field. All inputs after the first password field will also be password fields. Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: ~canceled: `True` if the user canceled the dialog box ~input[1]: The contents of the first input field ~input[2]: The contents of the second input field ~input[3]: The contents of the third input field Version: 18-07-26 - Charles Ross Notes: If the Btns parameter is provided, the last button will be the cancel button.

ScriptReference.name: dialog priv: Begin Loop ( Title ; BaseMsg ; Inputs ; Tests ; Msgs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )
dialog: Edit ( Auth ; Layout ; ID {; Callbacks } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Opens the specified popin layout for record editing. Parameters: Auth: `True` if access is allowed, an error message to display to the user otherwise. Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. ID: The primary key of the record to edit. Callbacks: Optional: A let-notation dictionary with the following possible keys: pre_commit: A script name to execute before committing post_commit: A script name to execute after committing post_close: A script name to execute after closing Return: none Version: 17-12-01 - Charles Ross 18-05-25 - Charles Ross - Fix variable typos 19-08-25 - Charles Ross - Take advantage of Perform Script by Name, conform to funit conventions in error reporting Todo: - Automate and abstract the feedback dialog for missing required parameters.

ScriptReference.name: dialog priv: Edit ( Auth ; Layout ; ID {; Callbacks } )
dialog: New ( Auth ; Layout {; Fields ; Values ; Callbacks } )

Comment.value: Purpose: This script (after rule evaluation) opens the specified popin layout and a record for editing Parameters: Auth: `True` if access is allowed, an error message to display to the user otherwise. Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. Fields: Optional: A let-notation array of fully-qualified field names (`GetFieldName ( field )`). Values: Optional: A let-notation array of values to assign to the fields in the Fields parameter. Count of each must match. Callbacks: Optional: A let-notation dictionary with the following possible keys: pre_commit: A script name to execute before committing post_commit: A script name to execute after committing post_close: A script name to execute after closing Version: 17-12-01 - Charles Ross 19-08-25 - Charles Ross - Conform to funit conventions in error reporting Notes: The `Fields` and `Values` parameters should be constructed using `let.Array`. Any name can be used, but it must be consistent for each parameter, i.e.: let.Array ( "Fields" ; 1 ; GetFieldName ( MOD::text_field ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 1 ; "first value" ) & let.Array ( "Fields" ; 2 ; GetFieldName ( MOD::date_field ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 2 ; "second value" )

ScriptReference.name: dialog priv: New ( Auth ; Layout {; Fields ; Values ; Callbacks } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Determines whether a popin can be committed. Parameters: IsValid: `True` if the commit has been validated or an error message otherwise. Calculation.Text: /*script.Param ( "Auth" ; True ) & script.Param ( "Layout" ; $$_DIALOG_TEST_LAYOUT_NAME ) & let.Array ( "Fields" ; 1 ; GetFieldName ( FUNITCF::function ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 1 ; $_function_value )*/
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "dialog module failed to create record" )
$_funitcf_count ≠ ExecuteSQL ( "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM FUNITCF" ; dev.Nil ; dev.Nil ) - 1
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "dialog module did not increment record count" )

Calculation.Text: /*script.Param ( "Auth" ; True ) & script.Param ( "Layout" ; $$_DIALOG_TEST_LAYOUT_NAME ) & let.Array ( "Fields" ; 1 ; GetFieldName ( FUNITCF::function ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 1 ; $_function_value )*/
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "dialog module failed to cancel record creation" )

let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "dialog module did increment record count" )

Comment.value: Purpose: Confirm that callback scripts get called correctly in the correct state Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: - ~success: `True` or `False` - ~error: Error text if an error occurred Version: 19-11-26 - Charles Ross

ScriptReference.name: dialog: New ( Auth ; Layout {; Fields ; Values ; Callbacks } )

Calculation.Text: script.Param ( "Auth" ; True ) & script.Param ( "Layout" ; $$_DIALOG_TEST_LAYOUT_NAME ) & script.Param ( "Callbacks" ; let.Set ( "pre_commit" ; "dialog: Pre Commit Callback" ) & let.Set ( "post_commit" ; "dialog: Post Commit Callback" ) & let.Set ( "post_close" ; "dialog: Post Close Callback" ) )
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "dialog module did not properly call the pre commit script" )
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "dialog module did not properly call the post commit script" )
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "dialog module did not properly call the post close script" )

ScriptReference.name: dialog priv: Begin Loop ( Title ; BaseMsg ; Inputs ; Tests ; Msgs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )

Comment.value: Purpose: Provide a looping custom message dialog box that returns up to three input fields after conditions have been met or the user has canceled. Parameters: Title: The dialog box title. BaseMsg: The beginning message for the dialog box which is append after any conditions fail. Inputs: The number of input fields, an integer from 0 to 3. Tests: A let-notation array of tests that should be passed. Each test should be `Evaluate`able. Msgs: A let-notation array of matching messages when conditions fail. Msgs and Tests must match in count. Btns: Optional: A let-notation array of button names, defaults to "OK" and "Cancel". If provided, must include at least two buttons. Labels: Optional: A let-notation array of labels. If not provided, no labels are given. PWStart: Optional: The first input field to make a password field. All inputs after the first password field will also be password fields. Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: ~canceled: `True` if the user canceled the dialog box ~input[1]: The contents of the first input field ~input[2]: The contents of the second input field ~input[3]: The contents of the third input field Version: 18-07-26 - Charles Ross Notes: If the Btns parameter is provided, the last button will be the cancel button. Todo: Shorten script by using subscripts, but get testing scripts in place first to make sure nothing breaks.

Calculation.Text: ( not script.AssignParams ) or ( $Inputs < 0 ) or ( $Inputs > 3 ) or ( not math.IsInteger ( $Inputs ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $Btns[1] ) and IsEmpty ( $Btns[2] ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $PWStart ) and ( not math.IsInteger ( $PWStart ) ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $PWStart ) and ( $PWStart > $Inputs ) )
"Invalid parameters were passed to " & Quote ( Get ( ScriptName ) ) & ". Please contact the developer."

ScriptReference.name: dialog priv: Validate Arrays ( Tests ; Msgs )
dialog priv: Show Dialog ( Title ; Msg ; Inputs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )

Calculation.Text: let.Set ( "~success" ; True ) & let.Set ( "~button" ; $~button ) & let.Set ( "~input[1]" ; $_input[1] ) & let.Set ( "~input[2]" ; $_input[2] ) & let.Set ( "~input[3]" ; $_input[3] )

ScriptReference.name: dialog priv: Show Dialog ( Title ; Msg ; Inputs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )

Comment.value: Purpose: Show the appropriate dialog given the parameters Parameters: Title: The dialog box title. Msg: The message to show in the dialog. Inputs: The number of input fields, an integer from 0 to 3. Btns: Optional: A let-notation array of button names, defaults to "OK" and "Cancel". If provided, must include at least two buttons. Labels: Optional: A let-notation array of labels. If not provided, no labels are given. PWStart: Optional: The first input field to make a password field. All inputs after the first password field will also be password fields. Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: ~canceled: `True` if the user canceled, `False` otherwise ~input_1`: The contents of the first first input field ~input_2`: The contents of the second first input field ~input_3`: The contents of the third first input field Version: 19-12-12 - Charles Ross

Calculation.Text: ( not script.AssignParams ) or ( $Inputs < 0 ) or ( $Inputs > 3 ) or ( not math.IsInteger ( $Inputs ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $Btns[1] ) and IsEmpty ( $Btns[2] ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $PWStart ) and ( not math.IsInteger ( $PWStart ) ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $PWStart ) and ( $PWStart > $Inputs ) )
"Invalid parameters were passed to " & Quote ( Get ( ScriptName ) ) & ". Please contact the developer."

let.Set ( "~success" ; True ) & let.Set ( "~canceled" ; $_canceled ) & let.Set ( "~button" ; $_last_message_choice ) & let.Set ( "~input[1]" ; $_input[1] ) & let.Set ( "~input[2]" ; $_input[2] ) & let.Set ( "~input[3]" ; $_input[3] )

ScriptReference.name: dialog priv: Validate Arrays ( Tests ; Msgs )

Comment.value: Purpose: Validate that the count of items in conditions and messages are the same. Parameters: Conditions: A let-notation array of conditions. Messages: A let-notation array of messages. Return: Nothing, but halts execution with a dialog box if there's a mismatch. Version: 18-07-26 - Charles Ross

Calculation.Text: "Invalid parameters were passed to " & Quote ( Get ( ScriptName ) ) & ". Please contact the developer."
"The script " & Quote ( Get ( ScriptName ) ) & " received mismatched numbers of conditions and messages. Please contact the developer."

Comment.value: Purpose: Opens the specified popin layout for record editing. Parameters: Auth: `True` if access is allowed, an error message to display to the user otherwise. Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. ID: The primary key of the record to edit. Callbacks: Optional: A let-notation dictionary with the following possible keys: pre_commit: A script name to execute before committing post_commit: A script name to execute after committing post_close: A script name to execute after closing Return: none Version: 17-12-01 - Charles Ross 18-05-25 - Charles Ross - Fix variable typos 19-08-25 - Charles Ross - Take advantage of Perform Script by Name, conform to funit conventions in error reporting

ScriptReference.name: window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Calculation.Text: script.Param ( "Layout" ; $Layout ) & script.Param ( "Style" ; "dimcard" ) & script.Param ( "Title" ; let.Get ( Get ( ScriptResult ) ; "~window_name" ) )
"The specified record (" & $_key_field & "=" & $ID & ") cannot be found. If this problem persists, please contact the developer."
"Multiple records were found with the specified ID (" & $_key_field & "=" & $ID & "). Please contact the developer."
$_error_capture_state = 0 // Error capture was off, return it to that state

Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. Fields: Optional: A let-notation array of fully-qualified field names (`GetFieldName ( field )`). Values: Optional: A let-notation array of values to assign to the fields in the Fields parameter. Count of each must match. Callbacks: Optional: A let-notation dictionary with the following possible keys: pre_commit: A script name to execute before committing post_commit: A script name to execute after committing post_close: A script name to execute after closing Version: 17-12-01 - Charles Ross 19-08-25 - Charles Ross - Conform to funit conventions in error reporting Notes: The `Fields` and `Values` parameters should be constructed using `let.Array`. Any name can be used, but it must be consistent for each parameter, i.e.: let.Array ( "Fields" ; 1 ; GetFieldName ( MOD::text_field ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 1 ; "first value" ) & let.Array ( "Fields" ; 2 ; GetFieldName ( MOD::date_field ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 2 ; "second value" )

ScriptReference.name: window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Calculation.Text: script.Param ( "Layout" ; $Layout ) & script.Param ( "Style" ; "dimcard" ) & script.Param ( "Title" ; let.Get ( Get ( ScriptResult ) ; "~window_name" ) )

Comment.value: Create the record and populate the fields.

Purpose: Determines if a popin window can be committed. Parameters: IsValid: `True` or an error message to present to the user. Return: `True` if window can be commited, `False` otherwise. Purpose: Record any sent callbacks in global variables Parameters: Callbacks: Optional: A let-notation dictionary with the following possible keys: pre_commit: A script name to execute before committing post_commit: A script name to execute after committing post_close: A script name to execute after closing Version: 19-08-25 - Charles Ross 19-11-26 - Charles Ross - Update variable names to reflect new module name

project 1.0.0 ============= The `project` module provides various tools to work with a FileMaker project, especially an open source one or simply one that will use source control. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library - This file's dialog module - FileMaker Server running locally on macOS - A git repository hosted on GitHub with a local copy Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from this file. 2. Import the `project` folder of scripts. 3. Edit the `project: Settings` script to set the following variables: - $_project_directory: The absolute path to the project's repository directory - $_key_file: The name of the file that will contain the encryption key - $_store_key_globally: If set to `True` the encryption key will be stored in a global variable on first read and read from that upon subsequent needs - $_fms_username: The username for using the `fmsadmin` command line tool - $_fms_password: The password for `fmsadmin`, expected to be encrypted with the key found in the key file, call `project: Encrypt ( { String } )` with no parameters to be prompted for a string to encrypt using the encryption key in the key file and receive the encrypted password in a dialog box where you can copy it. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- When you're ready to create a new commit, execute `project: Commit`. This script will perform the following steps: - Prompt the user for a commit comment - Create a new backup of the current file and move the backup to the project folder - Save the file's XML representation - Add all files in the project folder to the git repository - Commit the files with the given comment - Push the repository to the server The ability to encrypt and decrypt data using an externally stored key first arose with this module, which is why it has that functionality. If you'd like to encrypt a string using the encryption key stored in the key file, call `project: Encrypt ( { String } )`. If you don't pass a parameter, you'll be prompted to provide the string in a dialog box. Similarly, to decrypt a string encrypted with the externally stored encryption key, call `project: Decrypt ( { String } )`. To Do ----- Support the ability to bypass pushing the repository Support the ability to store hosted files in subfolders Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 20-01-10 [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: Return a let-notation structure of the settings needed for the module. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with the following additional keys ~project_directory: The directory where the DDR should be stored ~key_file: The name of the file in the project directory that stores the encryption key ~store_key_globally: If `True`, the encryption key will be stored in a global variable the each time it's retrieved (`$$_PROJECT_MODULE_ENCRYPTION_KEY`), defaults to `False` ~fms_username: The username to use when accessing the server with `fmsadmin` ~fms_password: The password to use when accessing the server with `fmsadmin`, expected to have been encrypted using the key in the key file Version: 20-01-10 - Charles Ross

primary-key 1.0.0 ================= The `primary-key` module provides a single place to let other modules know how to identify a table's primary key. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the chiv-lib file. 2. Import the `primary-key` folder of scripts. 3. Edit the `primary-key: Config` script so that it the $_pk variable stores the name of the field used as a primary key. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- Modules can call the `primary-key: Primary Key Name` script. It will return a let-notation dictionary with a key of "~pk_name", which will have the primary key name for its value. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 17-11-08 [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: none Parameters: none Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with the following additional key: ~pk_name: The name of the primary key field Version: 19-08-10 - Charles Ross
DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE

Purpose: Checks that the primary key provided exists in at least one table that has multiple records. Parameters: PKName: The name of the primary key to check. Return: `True` if the primary key is valid, halts script execution otherwise. Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross Notes: Halts script execution on error.

Purpose: Confirm that the primary key is returned from the module Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: - ~success: `True` or `False` - ~error: Error text if an error occurred Version: 19-08-17 - Charles Ross

Purpose: Checks that the primary key provided exists in at least one table that has multiple records. Parameters: PKName: The name of the primary key to check. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with the following additional keys: ~pk_name: The name of the primary key field Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross 19-08-17 - Charles Ross - Edit to work with funit module
Find a table with more than one record.

Calculation.Text: "The script " & Quote ( Get ( ScriptName ) ) & " encountered an error. At least one table must have more than one record. Please contact the developer."
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "No tables with multiple records" )

Comment.value: Check that the field exists.

Calculation.Text: Let ( [ _sql = List ( "SELECT " & Quote ( $~pk_name ) ; "FROM " & Quote ( $_table ) ; "FETCH FIRST ROW ONLY" ) ] ; ExecuteSQL ( _sql ; dev.Nil ; dev.Nil ) )
$_result = "The column named " & Quote ( $PKName ) & " does not exist in any table in the column reference's scope."
"The script " & Quote ( Get ( ScriptName ) ) & " expects a string that corresponds to a field name. " & Quote ( $Key ) & " does not. Please contact the developer."
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "Named primary key doesn't exist in table" )

Comment.value: window 1.0.0 ============ The window module provides a scripts to create generic windows for both the users and developers. Requirements ------------ - This file's custom function library Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the chiv-lib file. 2. Import the `window` script folder and all of its sub-folders and scripts into your solution. See the comments within the `Script Parameter Passing Readme` for instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- When a new window is needed, call the `window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )` script. See the header comments for this script for details about the available parameters. If you need a window for context control, and therefore want it created offscreen for end-users but onscreen for developers, call the `window: New Utility ( Layout {; WindowID } )` script. This script will return the name of the window so that the calling script can close it. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 17-11-08 [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

ScriptReference.name: window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Creates a new window with the given parameters. Parameters: Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. Title: The title to give to the window. Style: Optional: Either "dialog" or "document", defaults to "dialog" Coords: Optional: The top and left coordinates where the window should be placed. If omitted, the window is centered within the parent window and offset 50 pixels from the parent window's top. Size: Optional: The height and width coordinates the windows should be sized to. If omitted, the width will be determined by `Adjust Window [ Resize to Fit ]` and the height by the minimum of that value and the parent window minus 100 pixels. Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross Notes: Coords and Size parameters should be specified using let-notation dictionaries. The keys for Coords should be `_top` and `_left` while those for Size should be `_height` and `_width`: let.Set ( "_top" ; 150 ) & let.Set ( "_left" ; 150 ) let.Set ( "_height" ; 600 ) & let.Set ( "_width" ; 600 )

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Creates a new window with the given parameters. Parameters: Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. WindowID: Optional: A unique ID for the window so it can be reliably closed later. Defaults to a UUID. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with additional key: ~window_name: The title of the window so the calling script can reference it if necessary Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New Utility ( Layout {; WindowID } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Confirm that new windows are properly created Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: - ~success: `True` or `False` - ~error: Error text if an error occurred Version: 19-08-16 - Charles Ross

ScriptReference.name: window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Calculation.Text: script.Param ( "Layout" ; $_layout ) & script.Param ( "Title" ; $_title ) & script.Param ( "Coords" ; let.Set ( "_left" ; $_left ) & let.Set ( "_top" ; $_top ) ) & script.Param ( "Size" ; let.Set ( "_width" ; $_width ) & let.Set ( "_height" ; $_height ) )

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Creates a new window with the given parameters. Parameters: Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. Title: The title to give to the window. Style: Optional: One of "dialog", "document", "utility", "card", or "dimcard", defaults to "document". Coords: Optional: The top and left coordinates where the window should be placed. If omitted, the window is centered within the parent window and offset 50 pixels from the parent window's top. Size: Optional: The height and width coordinates the windows should be sized to. If omitted, the width will be determined by `Adjust Window [ Resize to Fit ]` and the height by the minimum of that value and the parent window minus 100 pixels. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross 19-09-13 - Charles Ross - Allow close boxes in document and utility windows Notes: Coords and Size parameters should be specified using let-notation dictionaries. The keys for Coords should be "_top" and "_left" while those for Size should be "_height" and "_width". Windows are only created offscreen for users. When developers execute this script, windows are positioned at (0, 0). 1. Use $Coords if provided 2. Lacking $Coords, default to parent + 50 3. If vertical size fits within parent, done. 4. If vertical size does not fit within parent, extend bottom. 5. If vertical size still does not fit, extend top.

Calculation.Text: Case ( dev.IsSet ( $Coords ) ; let.Get ( $Coords ; "_top" ) ; Let ( [ _default = $_parent_top + 50 ; _top = Case ( _default + $_height > Get ( ScreenHeight ) ; Get ( ScreenHeight ) - $_height ; _default ) ] ; _top ) )

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New Utility ( Layout {; WindowID } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Creates a new window with the given parameters. Parameters: Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. WindowID: Optional: A unique ID for the window so it can be reliably closed later. Defaults to a UUID. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with additional key: ~window_name: The title of the window so the calling script can reference it if necessary Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Calculation.Text: "Duplicate this table to create a new table with the standard fields."
